segments.text: May 9, Kerrville, Texas, getting ready to head back.
During those years, in the early 60s, some other memorable colleagues were Charles Wines, W-Y-N-E-S.
Tall, thin, reserved Virginian.
scholar of the New South.
My second year as a faculty member at A&M, I moved from the large office, which I had occupied during that first temporary year, to the third floor where Charlie and I shared an office for a year.
He was a
Thoughtful kind.
Colleague, although always reserved.
Another Garland Bayless.
Whose area also was the New South?
He and his wife Mary Evelyn became.
Two of our dearest friends.
For all our decades.
His work was always marked by deep concern for students as well as an abiding diligence in community activities.
Tom Miller, quietly effective in Texas history, a thorough researcher,
sometimes said by the students not to be very, quote, entertaining in class.
The department had grown greatly during the late 50s because in the middle of that decade, the state legislature responding to the McCarthy era and the supposed threats of communism

had passed laws requiring that everyone every student at a public institution in texas take six hours of american history and that plus three hours of u.s government and that all teachers although who would be certified as

public school teachers in the lone star state must take three hours of texas history thus there was a an immediate need to add to the department the appointments during that period for example included lloyd taylor and garland bayless
By my third year, I was assigned to an office on the east end of the third floor of Nagel Hall.
By current standards, it might seem like a comparatively compact place, but as a beginner, as an instructor in rank, I felt very flattered.
Under Dr. Nance's leadership, all beginning faculty members served three years at the rank of instructor and then three as, a minimum of three as an assistant professor.
During that time, I benefited from one of President Rutter's directives.
Apparently he had gone to a national meeting
Where some speaker?
Emphasized the need.
For.
Review.
Of performance.
And reward on a merit salary basis.
On confidential.
Standard.
Mr Rudder.
ask the deans to direct the department heads to submit a list during the fall semester of all faculty members in each department ranked according to their merit performance.
Rumor had it
that John Pearson, who led business administration at that time, refused to comply with that directive and earned at least the temporary displeasure of President Rudder.
We rank and file faculty were unaware of that directive, but I became
learned about it when I was notified that I had received a $100 a month increase, a very meaningful salary move for a junior faculty member at that time.
Another involvement which proved to be
long-lasting was becoming the opportunity to become acquainted with J. Wayne Stark, that's initial J and then W-A-Y-N-E-S-T-A-R-K, the founding director of the Memorial Student Center.
Future
future acquaintance with him would demonstrate that he was a tireless and always optimistic crusader for what was best for the entire institution.
He was a self-appointed campaigner for the fine arts, leadership development,
and had an innate ability to identify individuals to draw, whom he would attempt to draw into the MSC's activities.
For example, if he learned about a freshman who seemed highly promising,
He would invite that student to his office and after a chat quite often would assign that student to be the, quote, aid, quote, or in fact errand runner for one of the key student body officers.
That would give the promising student a bird's eye view.
For example, a young freshman named Kent Caperton, K-E-N-T-C-A-P-E-R-T-O-N, who had come to A&M in the mid 60s,
from his home in Caldwell where he had been president of the student body and had earned the respect of both the high school faculty and his fellow students.
Someone called young Caperton to the attention of Mr. Stark and so
Under the, quote, Stark system, quote, Kent became the assistant to the MSC, to the student body president.
His sophomore year, as was usual, he disappeared, meaning he was no longer highly visible.
because he was working in the, on the, he was proceeding at the true working level of student activities.
By his sophomore year he reemerged, by his junior year he reemerged as a student body leader and then was elected president of the A&M student body his senior year.
The same thing had occurred a few years a similar series of events had occurred just a bit earlier.
Mr. Stark and a few others had gathered to try to consider how A&M could attract

more highly promising Hispanic students because it seemed that in the coming decades the Mexican-American percentage of the state's population would grow very sharply and A&M would need to have some of its graduates in that
leadership group if the land-grant school for Texas was to prosper.
With the assistance of Buck Wirus, the always energetic director of the Association of Former Students,
the staff of the Registrar's Office Stark and others tried to identify some very promising students.
As they said, they went after those young men with rifles,
instead of shotguns, and of the 15 who were sought, 12 enrolled.
By the time they became part of the Stark system in their freshman year and were aides to many of the key student body leaders.
Again, they disappeared from
view as sophomores, then reemerged as juniors as the vice president, vice chairman, and or otherwise second in command of their group.
Then as seniors, it seemed that they, quote, took over the campus because Henry Cisneros became band commander.
and Hector Gutierrez, the commander of the Corps of Cadets, the first minority individual to hold that role.
A classic bit of Aggie, true Aggie mythology occurred when
Hector returned back to his home in Laredo, where the celebration of his appointment was held in true Aggie fashion at the Cadillac bar in Nueva Laredo, a famous establishment
led by Porter Garner Jr., an Aggie class of 45.
Another classic Wayne Stark practice was identified as the green couch treatment.
Quotation marks around green couch treatment.
This unforgettable encounter occurred after the MSC director learned that a highly promising student was not living up to his potential.
and instead was loafing.
Stark would maneuver the youngster to his office.
After closing the door, he seated the visitor
on an old couch covered with notably outdated green vinyl.
Then the young man received
a life-changing, what often proved to be a life-changing lecture about the foolishness of laziness, the foolishness of failure, the obligation to serve
and the quiet honor of service and reliability.
By the
Fairly early in my A&M years, Mr. Stark invited me to serve as one of the advisors to SCONA, S-C-O-N-A, the Student Conference on National Affairs.
Then a truly notable effort held about during the first week of December.
It was a conference for 500 or more delegates

from colleges and universities scattered all across the nation, particularly including the notable institutions on the east and west coast, service academies, plus almost every institution in the southwest.
The students raised the money by calling on NM former students, Texas corporations, and their own family friends.
The speakers were always
individuals of high merit and notoriety.
One unforgettable moment in that tradition came in 1962 when the Vice President of the United States, Lyndon Baines Johnson, came to speak
to a packed house at G. Reilly White Coliseum.
His older daughter, Linda Byrd, then a freshman at the University of Texas at Austin, came over to hear her father's remarks.
Came over that morning to hear her father's remarks.

In the era of an all-male student body, the commander of the Corps of Cadets invited this attractive Longhorn visitor to be his guest at the Duncan Dining Hall where the entire Corps would enjoy her presence.
Since the Longhorn football team.
Had just.
Obliterated.
The Aggies.
On Thanksgiving Day.
With a runaway score.
It seemed appropriate to repay.
To quote repay the quote.
This representative of the Longhorns.
So.
In the near the middle of the meal.
All of the fish in the core.
Jumped up.
And in perfect Aggie order.
Yelled I yelled.
Beat the hell out of tea.
Yeah, yeah, yeah.
They then stared quietly.
At the one young lady in the room.
Who stared?
Back at them.
as she placed her knife and fork back on the table, then lifted her napkin from her lap, stood up very erectly, pushed her chair under the table, and stared back at the now silent
Aggie audience.
Then she yelled out with her hands raised high above her head
fore and little fingers extended in each palm as she proclaimed, hook them horns.
Immediately the Aggies jumped to their feet, applauded her, and everyone in the audience smiled.
As a footnote, it seems appropriate to add at this point

But 18 years after this event, my wife and I, almost 18 years after this event, my wife and I attended our first meeting of the University of Texas Board of Regents following our appointment to lead the University of Texas at El Paso.
At a dinner party the first night of the meeting served at the president's residence in Austin.
We were near the head of the line.
And took our plates.
Into the library area of that beautiful home.
And we're about to sit down.
When the.
wife of the former president of the United States, came into the room.
We thought it would be appropriate to go over and introduce ourselves to Mrs. Johnson.
And after the first formal words, I then recounted this episode involving her daughter
at A&M in 1962.
When I concluded, she instantly smiled, leaned over and said, proudly, that's my girl.
Looking back on the role of the MSC, Wayne Stark
with Wayne Stark as its director, and many, many organizations, campus organizations tied there, it is clear that he played a truly significant role in student development at that time.
Although there was a dean of students in those years, it did not then or now seem that that office was very significant in generating activities which would
polish the leadership talents of the students.
It was Stark who brought the art and the music and he and his associates encouraged the students to become involved and develop their talents.
In addition,
He was an old friend with the then dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Business who had grown up in Bryan and was at that time the only non-Harvard graduate to serve as dean at the first
institution of higher education created in the United States.
Can't think of his name, last name, Robert something or other.
We'll get it later.
Dozens of youngsters with maroon and white blood were admitted to Harvard, to the Harvard MBA program

simply on the basis of a phone call from the director of the Texas A&M MS Memorial Student Center to that dean who had learned that a stark recommendation could always be relied upon as a sound judgment of high capability
and splendid potential.
To a new faculty member of the Corps of Cadets was hard to understand.
That was particularly so for

A person whose father, whose cabinetmaker father, on a few occasions indicated that he thought his son ought to go to Texas A&M because of that father's recollection that during the Depression, A&M graduates, quote, were able to keep their job
while others got laid off.
That view probably was correct because engineers and agriculture majors were in high demand as the country was trying to recover from its greatest economic failure.
But to this
young high school kid there seemed no attraction to go to a school that was all male and where every student had to be wear a uniform in the Coral Cadets for at least the first two years.
After seeing Aggies quote misbehave quote at the Rice football games
A&M seemed, some of the A&M's practices seemed even more of an anomaly.
For example,
